Some minor comments but overall LGTM

IMHO the config should be pulled from a central config rather than being per coordinator. In the extreme case you can have rolling upgrades taking place where some coordinators have kill ON and others have it off, and weather it is on or off in the cluster depends on who has leadership at the time.
Since this is recommended OFF in production, I'm ok as is though.

ASSUMING there are two magic ClassLoaders whose parents are the System classloader... and one ClassLoader is druidClassLoader, and the other is hadoopClassLoader... where the druidClassLoader has all the stuff that druid jars link to, and hadoopClassLoader has all the stuff hadoop things link to, then I would _think_ you would want any hadoop classes loaded by ONLY the hadoop classloader, and to have those classes only be aware of their library compatible versions. And any druid classes to ONLY call druid classloader stuff.... EXCEPT for hadoop classes, which will need to be loaded from the hadoopClassLoader.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MAPREDUCE-1700 is worth a read-through.

Since hadoop has some level of OSGi awareness (I have not looked into it much) it may be easier to figure out how to bundle the druid jars in an OSGi friendly way.

I think whether multi value should be sorted should be discussed. 
In some scenario multi value sorted can also make scene. For a multi value dimension expressing the properties of something, like a=b,c=d，the separator is ",". In this case, I'd rather treat "a=b,c=d" and "c=d,a=b" as the same value
Why do you say it is not?

I ask because of 
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2124
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2123
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2122
being due to lifecycle.stop() not being able to be called multiple times without errors
oh I see now. ha! yeah, that needs fixed.

Looks good to me! Thanks for the catch. All my comments are minor and I'm fine if it goes in as is :+1:
How appropriate is it to make this a `@Rule` instead of having to explicitly call stop?
@drcrallen stop() is called implicitly on close of the server, so I have closed this PR.

We also need to add to the release notes that you need to make sure your `druid.selectors.coordinator.serviceName` is set properly. Otherwise realtime indexing will stop working after updating because the handoff notifier won't be linked up.
@drcrallen Revised concurrent stop threads to wait completion of shutdown process. Is this better?
@KurtYoung Thanks for the explanation. I think this should be optionized in somewhere. For now, I'll restore sorting part. Let's do the optionizing in following issue.

each individual test has a 10s timeout, and there should be 8 of them, meaning less than 2 minutes worth of tests if each surpasses its maximum timeout. So that leaves me to believe there's a `@Before` or `@After` problem. So I'm checking that out next

@himanshug, please find the information below as we discussed.

Though this is not recommended to be used on prod, but we are looking for it to be used on prod. I feel this is a very useful operational feature. I believe doing things manual has chance of fat-fingering interval or datasource and these steps generally don't go through the review process unlike code or config.

I have couple suggestions to add as requirements, which also might help in reducing the risk of loosing data that we don't want to loose.

So, two suggestions:
1. Making the retention configurable - saying N hours, N days, N weeks, N months, N years. This gives the ability to define the interval of data that's useful to the system (which might be reloaded when there's a need), whether those segments are being marked as used or not in the metadata system. It means that data is meaningless beyond this retention period.
2. Making the datasources configurable - list of data sources to be considered for deletion. This gives you the ability to whiyelist the datasource that you want to consider for delete instead of taking all the datasources in the system.

If we're going to label it ready for production I would really like for the behavior to not change based on coordinator leadership.

A `druid.coordinator.kill.durationToRetain` should default at maximum value.
@drcrallen that means making all kill configuration be dynamic configuration so that all coordinator see same values irrespective of local runtime.properties config?

@fjy New failure I saw was regression in prior version of this pr :)

@drcrallen filter in DimensionSpec only make sense for multi-valued dimensions. Existing [Regex]Dim filter is used to select row from segment. one row would explode into multiple rows based on multivalued dimension. Then DimensionSpec filter would apply on these exploded rows and select from them.
In many cases the regex pattern used might be same in both places but it can be different as well depending upon the use case.
